Um the way I think about point point source versus direct air capture in terms of the tradeoff is like with point source it's great that the concentrations are really high that helps you energetically. But you want to capture as you know close to 100% of the well you know as much of the CO2 coming from point source as possible.

meeting_annotations.speaker: David Gator Kwabi
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um whereas with air capture the concentration is a bit lower but you might imagine you know there you you're sort of uh in terms of the amount you need to capture um you know you know atmosphere is just sort of sort of 400 ppm so you sort of have a constant PCO2 source.

meeting_annotations.speaker: David Gator Kwabi

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um one uh one topic that I'll throw out there for you all to think about that I haven't heard anybody discuss in this context is if we imagine deploying direct air capture on a large scale um regardless of what approach we use whether we use liquids or solids inorganic structures organic structures probably they're going to create some emissions themselves. Maybe they're going to be VOCs, maybe they're going to be particulates.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um but I to my knowledge nobody has really considered that as a research topic or a research area and nobody has looked at how emissions associated with these chemical plants which effectively is what they are how that's going to intersect with current atmospheric chemistry from a from a

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones
meeting_annotations.transcript: a traditional pollution perspective as opposed to a obviously it's it's removing CO2 pollution but it might be introducing new types of pollution that I don't think anybody has thought about.
